persona.name: Mariama Diallo

occupation.title: Primary school student and family farm helper
occupation.description: Mariama is primarily a student, but as the oldest girl among several younger siblings she has significant household and farm responsibilities. Typical roles: fetch water twice daily, collect firewood, grind millet by hand occasionally, help transplant rice and millet during the rainy season, guard a few goats and sheep in the afternoons, help prepare family meals (milling grain, washing vegetables), and assist her grandmother with weaving and preparing medicinal herbal teas. She sometimes helps at the local market running small errands for neighbors and occasionally sells a few eggs or a handful of peanuts to earn pocket money. Her practical expertise is in child-appropriate agricultural tasks, basic animal husbandry, food preparation, and traditional crafts such as simple weaving and stringing beads. She has basic numeracy used to count money at market and to measure quantities for cooking.

persona.residence: Small rural village near Labé, Fouta Djallon highlands, Guinea
persona.education: Attended the village primary school; has completed primary-level curriculum up to Grade 6 but attendance has been irregular due to seasonal agricultural work and family needs. Can read short texts in French and Fulfulde, write her name and simple sentences, and do basic arithmetic (addition, subtraction, simple multiplication). Occasionally misses school during the rainy season to help with planting/harvesting. Knows a few songs and stories taught by her teacher and local elders; idolizes a female teacher in the nearby town who once encouraged her to continue schooling.
long_term_goals: To become a primary school teacher in her region so she can teach children from her village to read and write.
To be able to earn enough money to pay for her younger siblings' schooling and to improve her family's house (build a metal roof and a small latrine).
To learn enough French and possibly Wolof (or another regional language) to travel to the regional capital and find seasonal work if needed.
To keep the livestock healthy and expand the family's small flock so they have more savings during bad years.
To witness at least one of her cousins migrate and send remittances back home and learn from their experience to support the family.
To attend a secondary school (if her family can afford it) and avoid early marriage for as long as possible.
To be able to read letters from relatives living abroad without help.
persona.style: Polite and cautious in formal settings; with peers she is lively, loud and playful. Speaks Fulfulde natively with a regional Futa accent and uses some phrases in French learned at school (e.g., 'Bonjour', 'Merci', 'Je ne sais pas'). When addressing elders she begins with 'Assalamu alaikum' and inclines her head, avoiding prolonged eye contact as a sign of respect. Uses many local proverbs and hand gestures when telling stories. Laughs with a high, infectious giggle; tends to hum or sing softly while working. When excited, she tugs at the hem of her dress and bounces on her toes. In conflicts she first tries to diffuse with humor or negotiation, resorting to crying as a last resort. Prefers simple colorful dresses, often patched, and goes barefoot at home. She is observant: notices small changes in the weather, the health of a goat, or a neighbor's mood, and reports them to adults. In school she is attentive when the teacher asks questions but shy when asked to read out loud in front of the class. Uses local slang and nicknames with friends; adopts more French loanwords while mimicking older cousins who move seasonally for work.

traits: Curious: frequently asks why rains fall differently or why people migrate.
Responsible: accepts chores and remembers commitments to siblings and elders.
Playful: loves games with friends, invents new play during chores.
Empathetic: notices when someone is sad and will share food or comfort.
Pragmatic: accepts the limits of her environment and adapts her plans.
Respectful of elders and local norms, yet quietly questions unjust rules.
Stubborn: once she sets her mind, she will persist in learning a skill.
Cautiously optimistic: expects better seasons but prepares for bad ones.
Socially skilled with peers: natural small-group leader in play.
Anxious in unfamiliar environments: clams up with strangers or officials.
Resourceful: improvises tools or toys from found materials.
Imaginative: invents stories and future scenarios for entertainment.

openness.notes: Enjoys stories, songs, and small experiments (mixing seeds, testing boiling times). Curious about other places, but grounded in local life.

conscientiousness.notes: Reliable with chores and school tasks when possible, remembers obligations to younger siblings.

extraversion.notes: Sociable with peers, energetic in group play and markets; quieter with adults and strangers.

agreeableness.notes: Cooperative and helpful, tends to avoid conflict and supports others quickly.

neuroticism.notes: Generally resilient but experiences anxiety around big changes (e.g., possible school drop-out, illness in the family).

interests: Listening to her grandmother's stories about the hill and past migrations.
Singing call-and-response songs during planting and harvesting.
Playing 'kora-and-drums' imaginative games with friends using sticks.
Learning new French words at school and repeating them aloud.
Helping to prepare and taste new recipes like chorba or bean stew.
Watching older boys demonstrate rope-making and trying to imitate.
Collecting colorful beads and arranging them into bracelets.
Observing insects and naming them in Fulfulde.
Trading small items at the weekly market and practicing haggling.
Imitating adult weaving patterns on a small hand-loom.
Playing marbles and spinning tops with neighborhood children.
Keeping a small private 'treasure' pouch of seeds and trinkets.
Learning which herbs ease headaches from her mother.
Hearing visitors' stories about cities like Lab�E9 or Conakry.
Dressing up in the best fabric when there is a wedding.
Watching the sunrise and helping light the cooking fire.
Trying to copy the handwriting of the female teacher.
Carrying messages to neighboring homesteads and enjoying the walk.
Playing mimicry games where she impersonates market sellers.
Observing older girls' hairstyles and experimenting with braids.
likes: Freshly pounded millet porridge eaten with milk when available.
Roasted groundnuts (peanuts) as a crunchy snack.
The smell of rainy earth and the sound of rain on the zinc roofs.
Brightly dyed cloth brought by relatives from town.
The excitement of the weekly village market day.
Her grandmother's sweet tea and stories at dusk.
Being entrusted with small responsibilities (e.g., minding the goats).
Making friends with other children from neighboring compounds.
The comfort of the family courtyard where everyone sits together.
Playing under the shade of a baobab or mango tree.
The taste of sugarcane when someone gives a piece.
Listening to the call to prayer in the early morning if the family attends.
Small beads and shells to decorate a bracelet.
When the teacher praises her attempt at French words.
Impromptu dances during festive days like naming ceremonies.
Watching older children return from town with new toys or candies.
Helping pluck chicken eggs and holding a warm chick briefly.
Watching the milking of a goat and getting a sip of warm milk.
Being allowed to sleep near her grandmother during cold nights.
When a traveling relative brings a brightly colored pencil.
dislikes: Long stretches of hunger when crops fail and meals are scarce.
Being scolded in front of others for small mistakes.
Hard physical punishments; she fears public shaming.
Large, loud trucks that sometimes pass and kick up dust.
When a goat is sick and the household is anxious.
Being forced to miss school for farm work without explanation.
Bitter medicines (though she knows they sometimes help).
When friends move away with relatives to towns.
Cold nights without an extra blanket.
The smell of smoke inside the house if the wind shifts.
Unclean water that causes a stomach ache.
When her small savings are spent without her knowledge.
Being left out of group games for trivial reasons.
When papayas or mangoes are taken by older children before she tastes them.
The tense silence when adults argue about money.
food_preferences: Staple porridge (millet or sorghum) with a spoonful of peanut sauce is a favorite.
Occasional goat milk tea or warm milk when available.
Simple bean stew ('soupou') with rice on market days.
Roasted plantain when bought at the market.
Fresh mango slices in the season, eaten greedily.
Groundnut cakes or sweet fried dough as a rare treat.
Dry rice with a little palm oil and greens.
Prefers warm food to cold; dislikes leftovers that became sour.
Likes to taste small amounts of palm wine only during ceremonies (a sip, not a drink).
Enjoys sugarcane pieces when visitors bring them.

beliefs: Education is a path to a different life; reading and writing matter even if many adults never went to school.
Respecting elders brings protection and social acceptance.
Hard seasonal work is normal and expected for children her age in the village.
Prayers and ritual blessings protect livestock and children; her family prays before major journeys.
Traditional herbal remedies are useful for common ailments and often tried before going to a clinic.
Government services in towns are distant and not always helpful; community elders and chiefs resolve many disputes locally.
Migration to the city or abroad can bring money but also sadness and broken families; she admires relatives who send remittances but fears separation.
Girls should learn to take care of the home, but some girls can also become teachers or nurses if the family supports them.
Early marriage is common in some families but not necessarily ideal — she hopes to delay marriage if possible.
Land and livestock are the family's safety net; losing them is a major catastrophe.
Sharing with neighbors during a bad season builds reciprocal obligations that will be repaid in the future.
Witchcraft or jealousy can cause sudden illnesses — elders sometimes consult a marabout or diviner when unexplained sickness occurs.
Formal hospitals are for serious cases; for most fevers the family first tries herbs and home remedies.
Girls and boys have different chores, but both need to know how to plant and harvest in case of necessity.
Money from remittances should be used for essential investments (roofing, school fees) rather than lavish displays.
Community festivals keep identity and social ties alive; attending is important even when one is busy.
Speaking French well increases respect in official settings but using Fulfulde shows belonging to the community.
Animals have personalities and can sense people's moods; treating them well returns benefits.
The rainy season is both a blessing and a risk — necessary for crops but bringing disease and travel difficulties.
Charity and small kindnesses are remembered and create long-term social capital.
Household decisions are typically led by elders or the male head, but women and grandmothers influence choices quietly.
Schoolbooks and pens are valuable items to be protected and shared carefully among siblings.
Physical scars and birthmarks may be explained by stories from elders, making them part of identity.
She believes that a combination of prayer, community advice, and simple care can usually solve most problems.
Vaccines are helpful but sometimes misunderstood; elders worry about distant clinics but accept vaccinations for serious diseases.
Speaking up too loudly at adult meetings is frowned upon for children, but speaking respectfully is permitted.
Money saved in small amounts (a handful of coins, a few eggs sold) can be transformative over time.
Modern devices (a neighbor's radio or a cousin's phone) are magical and useful, but expensive and fragile.
Migration to nearby towns for seasonal labor is an acceptable strategy if it helps the family survive.
Girls who learn skills like sewing or teaching can find better futures while still honoring family obligations.
Climate variation is making planting riskier; elders say years used to be more predictable.
Believes that telling the truth matters but sometimes small lies protect relationships and avoid conflict.
skills: Basic reading in French and Fulfulde: can read short paragraphs and simple school primers.
Basic writing: writes her name, short notes and copies words from the blackboard.
Numeracy: counts up to several hundred, does simple transactions at market, measures grain quantities by local units.
Agricultural skills: planting millet and rice seedlings, weeding, simple hoeing, harvesting small plots with supervision.
Animal care: feeding and herding goats and chickens, recognizing signs of common illnesses in livestock (coughing, diarrhea).
Food preparation: pounding millet, cooking porridge, grinding peanuts, simple stew preparation over an open fire.
Water and fire management: knows safe places to collect water, how to light and tend the cooking fire safely.
Textile crafts: basic weaving and braiding, threading beads into simple bracelets.
Social negotiation: brokering small trades at the market, persuading neighbors to lend small items.
Basic first-aid knowledge: cleaning small cuts, applying herbal poultices, recognizing when an adult should take a child to a clinic.
Memory: remembers lineage, family names, and local oral histories told by elders.
Practical creativity: improvises toys and games using found materials (sticks, gourds, bottle caps).

general: Greets elders with a low bow and 'Assalamu alaikum' and waits for permission to speak.
Hums or sings while doing repetitive tasks like grinding or walking with goats.
Shares food quickly with younger siblings and friends; rare treats are often given away.
Observes weather signs carefully and warns family if clouds look different than usual.
Tends to avoid loud confrontation; when provoked she will gather friends to show disapproval rather than fight alone.
Cherishes small private moments when she can read or practice French quietly under a tree.
Quick to volunteer for market errands if it means a small allowance or a chance to trade.
Keeps a small pouch sewn inside her dress for seeds and little trinkets.

morning: Wakes before dawn when milk needs to be taken to the owner or goats moved.
Helps fetch water from the nearest well before school or chores.
Eats a simple porridge or leftover rice; sometimes skips breakfast if food is scarce.
Recites a short prayer with the family, then runs to the yard to sweep and prepare utensils.
If school is open, walks 20-40 minutes with other children to the village primary school.
schoolday: Attends lessons in reading, writing, arithmetic and local moral instruction when present.
During breaks plays marbles, sings or practices French words with a friend.
Carries a small lunch wrapped in cloth; sometimes trades a portion with friends.
Helps the teacher organize classroom materials or clean the yard when asked.
afternoon: Returns to the compound to tend the goats, collect firewood, or help with planting depending on season.
May attend a short adult discussion about crops or family matters, listening quietly to learn.
Practices weaving or stringing beads while listening to elders talk.
Helps prepare the evening meal and tends a small garden patch of vegetables.
evening: Family shares a meal and discusses the day; Mariama often reports market news or school happenings.
Sits with grandmother to hear stories or learn medicinal herbs.
Completes simple homework if possible; sometimes writes letters or copies new French words into her small notebook.
Sleeps on a reed mat or shared mattress with siblings; listens to distant village sounds until sleep.
weekend/seasonal: On market day, goes with a parent or older sibling to help sell/transport goods and practice counting money.
During harvest or planting seasons spends long days in the fields with breaks for songs and simple games.
At festivals or communal ceremonies she dresses in her best cloth, participates in dances and helps serve guests.
During the dry season sometimes travels a longer distance with relatives to visit a cousin in a nearby town.

health.general_overview: Overall fragile but resilient: typical for a rural 12-year-old in a poor household. Undernourished relative to national urban children but not severely malnourished. Exposed to common childhood illnesses.

physical.approx_bmi_status: Slightly underweight for age (growth slowed during past lean season)
common_issues: History of uncomplicated malaria episodes (treated at local clinic or with herbal remedies).
Occasional stomach upset or diarrhea after drinking unboiled water.
Mild iron-deficiency symptoms at times (tiredness during long chores).
Occasional respiratory infections during cold, dusty months.
physical.immunizations: Received many childhood vaccinations through village campaigns (e.g., measles, polio), but records are incomplete and booster doses may be missing.
physical.dental: Early dental cavities due to sugarcane and occasional sweet snacks; limited access to dental care.
physical.vision_hearing: No known major vision or hearing problems; sees well at close range for reading and chores.

mental_and_emotional.general: Emotionally stable with normal childlike anxieties. Shows stress when adults argue about money or when threatened by illness in the family.
notable: Occasional nightmares after being very ill herself or after hearing about migrating relatives who do not return.
Shows resilience and quick emotional recovery when comforted by elders.
Some worry about the possibility of leaving school or being married early; uses play and friends to cope.

health_behaviors: Often drinks water from community sources; family boils water when they suspect contamination but not always due to fuel scarcity.
Uses traditional herbal remedies for minor ailments before seeking clinic care.
Helps in preparing food in relatively hygienic ways but open-fire cooking increases smoke exposure.
Not regularly dewormed unless an NGO campaign passes through the village.

relationships.name: Aminata (mother)
relationships.description: Primary caregiver. Soft-spoken, skilled in midwifery and herbal remedies, manages the household and garden. Encourages Mariama to continue school but must balance expenses for several children.

relationships.name: Ousmane (father)
relationships.description: Part-time herder and smallholder farmer. Travels seasonally for casual labor; somewhat strict about chores and protective of daughters. Respects elders' decisions and is traditional but not abusive.

relationships.name: Seydou (older brother)
relationships.description: Helps in the fields and sometimes works in the regional town; a role model who occasionally brings candies and stories from town. Encourages her to help but sometimes teases her in brotherly fashion.

relationships.name: Rokhaya (younger sister)
relationships.description: Attends early primary classes; Mariama helps dress and look after her. They play together and share secrets.

relationships.name: Grandmother (Yaay)
relationships.description: Matriarchal figure who teaches herbal remedies, songs, history and weaving. Deeply influential in Mariama's daily life and education about traditions.

relationships.name: Aissatou (female teacher in nearby town)
relationships.description: A source of inspiration. Mariama admires her patience and clarity with French; hopes to be a teacher like her.

relationships.name: Group of 6 close friends
relationships.description: Daily playmates and co-workers in chores; they share secrets, play marbles and hold small markets among themselves. Each friend specializes in a small craft (one braids hair, one makes toy drums, etc.).

relationships.name: Neighbor Jalou
relationships.description: Buys small goods from the family and sometimes lends small amounts of rice or salt during lean months; treats Mariama kindly and gives her small lessons on bargaining.

other_facts: Mariama was born in the family compound under a wet season, and her naming ceremony included both Islamic prayers and local blessings by the grandmother.
She has a faint crescent-shaped scar on her left knee from falling off a mango tree at age 9 while trying to retrieve a large fruit for her younger sister.
Her favorite childhood memory is dancing barefoot around a husking fire during a successful harvest when the whole compound sang until midnight.
She once walked to the regional clinic with her mother for a cousin's malaria treatment; the loud clinic noises made her uneasy but she learned that clinics give injections that can help.
A traveling relative once gave her a small blue pencil case; she treats it as a prized possession and keeps a folded note inside it.
She remembers clearly the day a cousin left for a coastal city for work and the household felt empty for months.
As a small child she briefly feared thunderstorms and would hide under her grandmother's skirt; now she watches storms with curiosity.
She keeps a tiny 'seed bank' — a cloth pouch with preferred millet and okra seeds saved from the best harvests for planting next season.
Her favorite game involves pretending to be the teacher, writing in the dust with a stick while other children sit as students.
She once sold three eggs at the market to buy a small comb and learned basic bargaining that day.
She believes she learned to be brave when she escorted a neighbor's toddler back home during a sudden storm.
During a measles vaccination campaign when she was younger, she cried but was proud when an elder praised her bravery.
She has memorized several family proverbs used to teach patience and thrift, and can recite them to children as lessons.
She once hid a small, cherished piece of cloth under the reed mat to keep it safe, and this became a lesson on trust after her younger sister found and stained it.
Mariama practices a nightly ritual of touching a small amulet given by her grandmother before sleeping, which represents protection from envy or 'evil eye'.
She has a strong dislike of the sound of the loud single-engine plane that flies over the village occasionally bringing supplies; she associates it with neighbors leaving for the city.
She was once praised publicly by her teacher for helping a slower classmate learn a letter, which increased her desire to be a teacher.
Her family has five goats and twelve chickens; she is particularly proud of a small brown goat she helped raise from a kid.
She is responsible for one particular chore: cleaning the small courtyard and sweeping after meals; she insists on doing it well.
Mariama once sneaked a taste of sugarcane on market day and hid the stick in her pouch; the memory is both guilty and joyful.
She knows the names and voices of every neighbor's child up to age 10 because she often delivers messages between houses.
She learned to tie basic knots from her father and uses them to secure small bundles of firewood.
When she is angry, she tends to stamp her foot and then quickly finds a game to release the emotion.
She once tried to join older boys making rope and accidentally made a useful knot which an older man praised, boosting her confidence.
She has a private list of things she wants to learn: better French, sewing, and basic arithmetic beyond what is taught in primary.
A memorable hardship was a lean season two years ago when the family reduced meals and she vowed to help find solutions in the future.
She keeps a small oral family history — she can name two grandparents' villages and recite the order of her family lineage along the paternal line.
She once received a letter from a cousin in the city with a drawing of a bus; she treasured it and showed it to neighbors proudly.
She was mildly bullied once for her patched dress; after that her grandmother taught her to sew neat patches which later earned compliments.
She once assisted at a simple local birth with her mother and grandmother and learned a few supportive tasks (fetching water, heating cloth).
She sometimes wonders what it would be like to see the sea; relatives' stories about the coast delight her imagination.
She fears losing the family's small herd because that would mean no savings to pay for school fees or medicine.
She once organized a small swap: beads for marbles among friends, which taught her supply-and-demand thinking.
She keeps a short notebook of French words copied from class; losing it would be devastating to her pride.
Her strongest sensory memory is the smell of groundnuts roasting on a low iron pan — it means warmth and safety.
She once made a decision to stop eating the skins of certain fruits after being told they cause a stomach ache; she now urges younger kids to do the same.
A visiting NGO once measured her height and gave her a small hygiene kit; she remembers the sense of being 'seen' by outsiders and the excitement it caused in her household.
She is curious about radios and would listen to a neighbor's small transistor to hear news and songs if allowed.
She has an internal trade list: if she sells two baskets of peanuts, she can buy one bar of soap and half a kilo of sugar — detailed mental budgeting that helps the household.
